results.title: Sheepdog
results.creator_credit: British Sccreen Service and John Alderson
results.brief_description: The work of a typical English dog in the wild Welsh mountains. A study of a shepherd’s workmate, his sheepdog; used to protect flocks from marauding foxes, to round up stragglers, and to rescue injured lambs or sick ewes.
results.description: The work of a typical English dog in the wild Welsh mountains. A study of a shepherd’s workmate, his sheepdog; used to protect flocks from marauding foxes, to round up stragglers, and to rescue injured lambs or sick ewes.

results.title: Sheep: handle with care. Parts I-III
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Bob Scarfe
results.brief_description: A three part program that shows the different aspects of sheep management. Part 1 deals with Mustering, mouthing, teeth trimming, drenching and foot care. Part 2 deals wth crutching, vaccinating, lamb marking and drafting. Part 3 deals with shearing, branding, dipping and jetting

results.brief_description: Illustrates the moods, rythms and images of sheep, using natrual sounds and no commentary. Shows sheep grazing, sleeping, waking and moving to the highlands.

results.title: Sheep ranching country: Southeastern Australia
results.brief_description: A study of sheep raising and wheat farming on the semi-arid plains region of South-Eastern Austalia. Emphasises the importance of wool and wheat exports to our economy.

results.title: Sheep on show
results.brief_description: A special sheep show was held in Melbourne at the time of the Olympic Games, and to further publicise the wool industry a large party of foreign journalists were taken on a tour of sheep studs which included Canberra, central Queensland, Alice Springs and Broken Hill. The film concludes with the Wool Fashion Award of 1957.

results.title: Sheep in wood
results.brief_description: The film presents Jacques Hnizodvsky wroking in his studio on a woodcut of two rams locked in combat. Uses close-up photography to show each step in the process of making a woodcut, from preliminary setches to the artist’s proof. There is no narration.

results.title: Sheep in the desert
results.brief_description: Shows how sheep can be raised successfully in low rainfall areas of Australia. It concentrates on one large station, Wilgena, nearly two million acres in extent and carrying 45,000 sheep. This station is self supporting, generating its own power and light, and is fitted with the most modern appliances. It produces sheep of fine quality and is entirely mechanised, the sheep being rounded up by men on motor bikes. In an area with an average rainfall of only 5 and a half inches, much needed water is supplied by sub-artesian bores. Vermin-proof fences check pasture destruction by rabbits and stock losses by dingoes.

results.title: Sheep's back
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Susan Ardill and Peter Butt
results.brief_description: Australia rode on the sheep’s back for over a century. Wool and the people who grew it became entwined with our national identity and the image of the sheep adorned postage stamps and coinage. The Country Party was a powerful force in Australian politics, however by the 1960’s it was Australia’s mineral deposits, particularly iron ore which began to dominate trade. As a consequence, rural Australians found themselves out of step with Australians living in our rapidly changing cities. This excellent documentary looks at the history of wool and examines what the future holds for those Australians who once rode upon the sheep’s back.
